hints_html:
Draw a diagram of the tank and see if you can interpret the question with the help of that diagram.

Recall that the work necessary to displace an object of mass m over a distance d is W = mgd.
hints_latex:
Draw a diagram of the tank and see if you can interpret the question
with the help of that diagram.

Recall that the work necessary to displace an object of mass \emph{m}
over a distance \emph{d} is \emph{W} = \emph{mgd}.
hints_raw:
Draw a diagram of the tank and see if you can interpret the question with the help of that diagram.
Recall that the work necessary to displace an object of mass ''m'' over a distance ''d'' is ''W'' = ''mgd''.
question: 3 (a)
sols_html:
To solve this problem, we consider moving up the liquid in the cylinder slice by slice.

Consider the slice of the cylinder of height dx as in the picture. Its volume is given by A dx where a is the area of the disc. This is

\[\begin{aligned} \pi (0.5)^2\,dx\end{aligned}\]

Its mass is thus

\[\begin{aligned} 1000 \pi (0.5)^2 \,dx = 250 \pi \,dx\end{aligned}\]

Since the density of the liquid is 1000 kg/m3. The work to lift the slice to the top is force multiplied by distance which is

\[\begin{aligned} 9.8 \cdot 250 \pi \,dx \cdot x = 9.8 \cdot 250 \pi x \,dx\end{aligned}\]

where x is the distance from the top of the cylinder to the slice.

Hence the total work is given by integrating this from the top to the bottom of the cylinder, that is from 0 to 2 and we obtain the integral

\[\begin{aligned} W = \int_0^2 9.8 \cdot 250 \pi x \,dx\end{aligned}\]

Consider the slice of the cylinder of height \emph{dx} as in the
picture. Its volume is given by \emph{A} \emph{dx} where \emph{a} is the
area of the disc. This is

\begin{align*}
\pi (0.5)^2\,dx
\end{align*} Its mass is thus

\begin{align*}
1000 \pi (0.5)^2 \,dx = 250 \pi \,dx
\end{align*} Since the density of the liquid
is 1000 kg/m\textsuperscript{3}. The work to lift the slice to the top
is \emph{force} multiplied by \emph{distance} which is

\begin{align*}
9.8 \cdot 250 \pi \,dx \cdot x = 9.8 \cdot 250 \pi x \,dx
\end{align*} where
\emph{x} is the distance from the top of the cylinder to the slice.

Hence the total work is given by integrating this from the top to the
bottom of the cylinder, that is from 0 to 2 and we obtain the integral

\begin{align*}
W = \int_0^2 9.8 \cdot 250 \pi x \,dx
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
To solve this problem, we consider moving up the liquid in the cylinder slice by slice.

[[File:Math_Exam_Resources_Courses_MATH101_April_2011_Question_3_(a)_picture_1.jpg|250px|right]]

Consider the slice of the cylinder of height ''dx'' as in the picture. Its volume is given by ''A'' ''dx'' where ''a'' is the area of the disc. This is
:<math>\pi (0.5)^2\,dx</math>
Its mass is thus
:<math>1000 \pi (0.5)^2 \,dx = 250 \pi \,dx</math>
Since the density of the liquid is 1000 kg/m<sup>3</sup>. The work to lift the slice to the top is ''force'' multiplied by ''distance'' which is
:<math>9.8 \cdot 250 \pi \,dx \cdot x = 9.8 \cdot 250 \pi x \,dx</math>
where ''x'' is the distance from the top of the cylinder to the slice.

Hence the total work is given by integrating this from the top to the bottom of the cylinder, that is from 0 to 2 and we obtain the integral
:<math>W = \int_0^2 9.8 \cdot 250 \pi x \,dx</math>
statement_html: A tank in the shape of a vertical circular cylinder 2 m high and with radius 0.5 m is filled with a fluid that has density \(1000 kg/m^3\). Write a definite integral that gives the work, in Joules, required to pump all the fluid to the level of the top of the tank. For acceleration due to gravity, use \(g = 9.8 m/s^2\). Do not evaluate the integral.
statement_latex:
A tank in the shape of a vertical circular cylinder 2 m high and with
radius 0.5 m is filled with a fluid that has density $1000 kg/m^3$.
Write a definite integral that gives the work, in Joules, required to
pump all the fluid to the level of the top of the tank. For acceleration
due to gravity, use $g = 9.8 m/s^2$. Do not evaluate the integral.
statement_raw: A tank in the shape of a vertical circular cylinder 2 m high and with radius 0.5 m is filled with a fluid that has density <math>1000 kg/m^3</math>. Write a definite integral that gives the work, in Joules, required to pump all the fluid to the level of the top of the tank. For acceleration due to gravity, use <math>g = 9.8 m/s^2</math>. Do not evaluate the integral.
